instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4L: What is PM_SLP_S4L? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4L, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Hi, 

Machine won't turn on/display, Board has short fan spins, magsafe light is orange.

- <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> Was corroded, so I replaced it and ran a jumper (picture)
- PPVRTC - Voltage is low. Has 3.42, but has drops on the line to about 2
- Voltage at <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> is 3.42


What other information can I get for you?

I have working board the exact same here to help trouble shoot

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: That looks no fun did you replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>? Also, are PP3v42 and PPBUS stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
- PPBUSG3H - 8.58 with drops to 8
- PP3v42 - 3.42V consistent
- <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> - 3.33-3.42 (moves around)
- Pin 1 on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>) - 3.33-3.42 (moves around)
- Pin 13 on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) - 3.42

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> has not been replaced

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: So it is power cycling. Check if CPU Vcore is pulsing too at L7310.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
L7310 is 1.7V then drops to 0

Thanks Duke

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: The usual suspects apply: <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area termination resistors and traces, J6100, crap under SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Thanks Duke,

I removed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and found this (Picture). Not sure if the tear is a big deal. Will continue by replacing <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Doesn't look dramatic, all pads are still there at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Thanks Duke

- The fan has spun up to full a few times while sitting on the desk.

- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4L</SIGNAL> is pulsing as is S5l

- CPU heat sink is getting real hot

- <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> has been replaced now, no change

- I checked around [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/e1-slg3nb148cv.html"]"<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>[/URL]  [LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=12px], <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area termination resistors and traces, J6100, crap under SMC"

I will proceed by double checking these areas. Any other suggestions?[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
 

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Another clue...

When I first plug it in, I get no fan spin. If I plug it in again, then I get short fan spins

(All measurements previously were taken with short fan spins)

I decided to measure the rails when there's no fan spin. I get S5 rails, but no S4.
Also Missing:
- <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL>

Sorry for the confusion

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: CPU getting real hot is NOT good. Resistance to GND on Vcore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
116 Ohms

Excuse the ignorance, does that mean anything?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: I found 3 solder balls just below the cpu at <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> - is this a done deal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: 116 is fine. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 checked for corrosion and possible corrosion under SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
Thank you.

Duke I found blue corrosion on the line to <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> (Photo), Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, nothing changed

WIll follow your instructions
